posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
How does your team primarily write commands?  

Commands can be created in two primary ways: either by defining a subclass of `Command` with overrides for lifecycle methods like `initialize`, `execute`, `isFinished`, and `end`, containing your command logic, or by passing your code as a callback (such as a method reference or lambda function) to a factory function or Command subclass constructor.  

Over the years, WPILib has been moving toward a more-functional, less object-oriented driven architecture, yet legacy subclass interactions remain popular as shown in previous polls.  

Please share how you primarily interacted with the Command-based framework this year. Feel free to provide additional details below.

posts.name: Josh P
posts.cooked: We started mostly inline (see the registerXXXX methods in RobotContainer here), but when my students needed to make Named Commands for use with pathplanner, they for one reason or another made explicit command classes for each (I was busy doing volunteer stuff during the time they developed this). This year, our subsystems were all either finite state machines or moving one control loop to a setpoint, so commands were simple calls to change the state of the subsystem, and most control code was handled in our subsystem periodic methods. I will try to remember to pick their brains on why they went that way and bring the feedback back to the thread. (In the past, we always did explicit classes, but this year we tried to stay inline for commands.)

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: Our were mostly in-line, with a couple of explicit classes used for more complex situations, such as aligning to a reef pole.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Noah Zemlin
posts.cooked: This year, our approach was also divided, typically depending on which programmer was handling the code. Last year, we used 100% explicit subclasses. For next year, I plan to guide the programmers toward near 100% inline or factory functions, except for highly complex commands with extensive logic, such as combined auto align plus scoring, which we handled this year. Reducing the 1000 different XYZCommand.java files significantly improved code readability and traceability.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked: We use inline for most of our really basic commands, but we tend to put a lot of logic into our commands and it gets unwieldy, so our default is still subclasses. We also like the convenience of referencing commands in command groups, and I’m not sure how we’d compose command groups of anonymous inner classes.

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: We started using command factories this year (thank you @bovlb!) for nearly all our commands, except for a few long sequences that had their own files. This approach saved us a significant amount of time compared to writing out entire files, and binding commands to buttons became much simpler and cleaner. Our robot this year didn't require a state machine-style control system, making it incredibly simple to run using a few preset sequences. From what I’ve observed, this is one of the key areas where command factories excel, so I’m excited to continue using this convention in the future!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Sure! Please provide the text or details you'd like me to process, and I'll assist accordingly.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
Here is the refined version incorporating the feedback while preserving the original meaning:

"Our students discovered that maintaining numerous small files facilitated tracking the complex interplay of various parallel, sequential, parallel, and sequential processes throughout the year, as well as managing multiple parallel experiments they conducted.

Another minor concern was the ability to log the currently active command, which necessitates assigning it a name, and ensuring that collections log accordingly. From what I know, neither the inline factories nor the WPILab collections support this feature."

This revision enhances clarity and flow, making the text more polished while retaining its technical accuracy.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: We did purely factory methods this year. It worked well for the most part, but we had to rebuild a layer of organization instead of using subclasses. For example, all our multi-system factories were combined into the Autos class along with other utility functions for choosing scoring operations. Some factories needed class-level objects like Trapezoid Profiles or SwerveRequests, so they were placed next to the factory methods. With clear comments, this could stay organized, but we ended up with the Drivebase class holding a lot of complex drivebase-specific commands, making the Autos class harder to read.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: This is my first year running programming for our team. Looking at our 2024 code, we used more command classes. For some reason, it seemed more complicated than creating inline commands to me. However, looking back, I actually think command classes are more readable. We mostly used inline commands until the week before competition, as our subsystems were still being developed. This meant we couldn’t test much of our code aside from the drive base. Then, realizing that a lack of command-based knowledge caused half of our inline commands to not function properly, we switched to command classes, and everything worked out fine. While there are still some aspects I'm figuring out, I find them significantly simpler to work with. Commands.runOnce() was used quite frequently, and my understanding evolved throughout the season, even though I ended up answering inline due to the numerous leftovers in the code.

posts.name: Sam Maier
posts.cooked:
Yes, that makes sense. The challenge I've faced is determining whether factory methods for creating robot components should be placed in Subsystems or as static methods within classes like RobotContainer or another global utility class. While Subsystems seem ideal for grouping related functionality, managing interactions when controlling multiple Subsystems simultaneously can become cumbersome.

Creating a large class containing all commands feels overwhelming, as it may lead to complexity over time. I am curious about the WPILib community's recommended practices for organizing such methods. Perhaps there's an established pattern that addresses this efficiently. Additionally, if my commands require interaction with more than one Subsystem, I wonder if they are handling too much. It might be better to create composite commands that delegate actions across Subsystems rather than having each command manage multiple systems. Conversely, if most commands interact with two or three Subsystems, maintaining a detailed command list with comprehensive documentation might be feasible.

The main consideration seems to be striking a balance between modularity and the ability of commands to handle multiple Subsystems without becoming overly complex. A potential solution is adopting a hybrid approach—utilizing static methods for straightforward operations while designating Subsystems for more specialized tasks. This strategy could help keep the code organized while preventing functionality from growing unmanageably.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Subsystems should expose their contracts as command factories within their own scope. Composite commands using multiple subsystems can be defined either in the `RobotContainer` or through some command factory helper class, into which the subsystems can be injected.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked: As explained in earlier threads, WPILib has been moving toward a more-functional, less object-oriented driven architecture for several years now. However, legacy subclass interactions remain quite popular according to past polls. Is there a good example of this? We've been pretty unhappy with the heavy object-oriented architecture and have gradually shifted toward a more functional approach, using many suppliers and lightweight state machines controlled by commands. Breaking old habits has been challenging, and I haven't yet seen a solid example of this—only discussions suggesting that "triggers are the new way most things should be handled."

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The Rapid React Command Bot example is the most architecturally up-to-date of the official examples at the moment. I know some people are working on documentation improvements this summer, so this may change.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked:
We only had commands returned from subsystem files, but everything was managed through an overarching "superstructure" class, which implemented a finite state machine. This structure heavily utilized Triggers to clearly define state transitions. For more details, refer to the provided file.

A big shoutout to team 8033 for this innovative state machine approach. Their method is highly recommended.

Here’s the cleaned-up version of the text, presented as a single, well-formatted paragraph:

Our programmers and I love inline commands. Our robot in version 24 didn’t need a state machine, allowing everything to be programmed as sequences. These commands were utilized in our NamedCommands for creating auto routines. Typically, our programmers create fundamental commands as subclasses, such as RunIntake or ShootCoral, and then employ the Command Factories API to link them into sequences. For instance, one might use joystick controls to trigger a multi-step process: initiating an intake and pivoting until algae detection is complete, followed by reversing the pivot. While this approach initially made the RobotContainer class cumbersome and difficult to navigate, attempting to implement an auto-alignment feature exacerbated these issues. Consequently, complex operations were relocated into dedicated Command classes to enhance clarity and maintainability.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
We switched to a mostly trigger-based architecture this year, inspired by discussions suggesting that triggers are becoming the primary method for handling various actions and reactions in robotics systems. As part of this approach, we created a single file containing multiple triggers that represent any action our robot takes or any measurement it needs to respond to. These triggers are then used to control commands within subsystems through a bindCommands() method executed during initialization.  

This system was heavily influenced by SpectrumLib, as demonstrated in a video by Allen (see [link](https://youtu.be/JMCk4XkBNCU?si=GiV7vqfT80B2YSb8)). The structure of our code, particularly in the RobotStates.java file (available on GitHub at [this link](https://github.com/suPURDUEper/2025-Robot-Code/blob/main/src/main/java/org/supurdueper/robot2025/state/RobotStates.java)), reflects this approach, though the full implementation may require further exploration.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Another minor issue we encountered was the need to log the active command, which requires a name. I recommend using the `withName(String)` decorator, which should be applied liberally in your command factories and wherever commands are being compounded.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
The following text has been cleaned up, preserving the original meaning while improving grammar and punctuation:

[truher] As I understand it, neither the inline factories nor the WPILib collections do that. Commands.idle().withName("Busywork") will do it. You just need this to be at the end of the composition (I think).  

This was the first year we **really** doubled down on a Trigger+Command factory interface. I found it worked quite well and was way cleaner than prior years using void doSomething() interfaces. On trivial commands, it was just less syntax, and on more complex ones (like trapezoidal profiles), it gave a single place to properly manage internal states.  

I think the biggest pain point we had in this transition was making it clear when commands end. We learned the hard way that most factories **should not** end by default. Then, either compose a condition, or have a secondary factory that does this as a shorthand.  

The only unresolved pain point we ran into was that we didn’t have a robust superstructure state machine flow. This turned out to be needed but haven’t exactly found something that vibes with our command flow patterns. It’s now the summer project.

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: Have you checked out the 8033 approach? I really liked it and found it really easy to implement. You can check out their code or ours for examples for this year.
